moves.1. e4 e5 2. Bc4: The bisschop's opening, my favorite. I love to attack and open games and in most of the cases this opening does lead to that kind of games
moves.4. b4: Evan's gambit, this is something new I found lately, if someone knows it's weaknesses or things you have to look out for, please put it in comment, thanks.
moves.4... Bxb4 5. c3 Bc5 6. d4: This is what Evan's gambit tries to do, gain a firm grip on the center at the cost of a pawn, which in this case seems to go fine.
moves.9. O-O: almost finishing development and stopping the e4 thread as 9. ... Qe4 is followed by 10. Re1! winning the queen.
moves.10. Bxb4 Nxb4 11. Nc3: some trades so my knight is safe on c3 protecting my e-pawn
moves.11... O-O: and now I'm starting to break up his development
moves.12. a3 Nc6 13. e5 Ng4 14. Nd5 Qd8 15. h4: I played this move to be able to play Ng5 followed by Qc2 threatening mate and some tactical positions.
moves.15... f6: ?? this I think is a blunder as it allows me to win a knight, however this isn't true as you'll find out later.
moves.16. Nxf6+ Kh8 17. Nxg4 d5: Well, this is why, I lose or my knight or my bisshop. I opt to 'sacrifice' my bisschop for more momentum on my attack by playing Ng5.
moves.18. Ng5 dxc4 19. Qc2: Qc2 tries for an obvious mate on h7, my opponents notices this and plays the best of 2 counters: Bf5
moves.19... Bf5 20. Qxc4: He can now win 2 knights for a rook, but he doesn't seem to want to and protects the check on f7 with his queen.
moves.21... Rad8 22. Rad1: the d-pawn is a key figure in my structure so I'm not allowed to lose it.
moves.22... h6: chasing my nicely placed knight but I can pin his rook for a mate.
moves.23. Nxf5 Rxf5 24. Qc2 g6: He treatens to take d4 now
moves.25. g4: and now I believe his best move was Rf4 winning at least two pawn in this sequence: 25. ... Rf4 26. Nh3? or is there a better move? 26. ... Rxg4+ 27. Kh2 Nxd4. but he opts for the trades with Nxd4.
moves.25... Nxd4 26. Rxd4 Rxd4 27. gxf5 Rg4+: I don't get this check why just don't take the knight? 27. ... hxg5 28. hxg5 Qxg5+and black wins with mate in two, the threats are dangerous then.
moves.28. Kh2 Rxh4+: with this move I can even hold on to my knight
moves.29. Nh3 Qxe5+ 30. f4: Blocked a probable huge amount of checks
moves.30... Qd4: keeping his queen on the a1-h8 diagonal so I can't check his king and waiting for me to move one of my pieces.
moves.31. Qxc7: I decided to grab a pawn here, because I believe he can't win anything down there.
moves.31... Qd2+ 32. Kg3 Rxh3+: Can anyone tell me why he would play this instead of Rh5? or Qd3+?
moves.33. Kxh3 Qd3+ 34. Kg2: from hereon I just have to escape his checks until I can move
moves.43... Qb3: The a-pawn is there to be taken, why play his queen there, it doesn't seem to help much more I think...
moves.44. Qd8+ Kg7 45. Qe7+ Kg8 46. Qe8+ Kg7 4: I will not give anymore comments further in the game as it is just a matter of trading queens and winning the game, thanks for reading, please rate and comment.
